text: going just Soofi muzzle hi everyone
Anthony Fantino here Internet's busiest
music nerd nice to meet you it's time
for an album review
ganja Sufi muzzle ganja Sufi is an MC
singer and producer who's been turning
heads ever since he landed as a guest
vocalist on the Flying Lotus album Los
Angeles which led him to get signed on
Warp Records to release his debut album
a Sufi and a killer which was one of my
favorite albums of 2010 and to this day
I have difficulty finding words to
accurately describe what this album is
it's kind of a weird mix of soul and
hip-hop and low fine music and
electronica and noise and funk and
Middle Eastern music punk and
psychedelic rock it's just a mess there
are so many songs on here it just kind
of uses being a mess as kind of a
concept
now after a remix album of that LP and a
new EP we have muzzle which is 10 new
tracks 24 minutes kind of a short mini
album and a slightly new direction first
off going to sufi is not working with
the Gaslamp Killer on this one he's
taken it upon himself to pull the
recording and the beats together and you
have a lot of lyrics on these tracks
that kind of deal in social overtones
and this stuff to me has kind of led to
a release that is a little bit more in
control of itself know if a Sufi and a
killer was kind of like this auditory
binge then this is definitely in
comparison much more focused and sober
I'm not saying this album isn't loaded
with trippy and psychedelic sounds
because it is like on the song feeding
birds you have these
vocals that sound like they're being
sung through McDonald's drive-thru
speaker boxes with lots of reverb on
them watery and reverb guitars just
shattering away in the background behind
them there all these swirls of just
ghostly vocals and electric piano on the
opening track white-picket-fence there's
some mutated King Crimson samples on
here with rubber band and skin and some
deep dark bass and an eerie atmosphere
surrounding the track venom kind of like
his last LP ganja Sufi comes up a little
short when it comes to presenting songs
but when it comes to putting sounds in
his album he's ahead of the curve tons
of sounds and colors and textures
flowing throughout this thing each song
on here is kind of like a starburst
nomnomnomnom not a really long lifespan
but just a an explosion of flavor which
to me is kind of especially true of
tracks like the the intro track and the
outro track which to me can only seem to
exist to throw some weird sounds out
there songs like black soot and skin and
time out there little meteor but I kind
of feel the same way about them too
because the beats behind the tracks just
the whole track in general just feels a
little repetitive kind of runs in
circles but those tracks a lot of tracks
on this LP you don't really last all
that long and while that keeps them from
getting really annoying to me they don't
exactly stick with me they're not really
packing a punch and many songs on here
don't really throw out ideas that
haven't already been thrown out by a
Sufi and the killer there are a few
darker beats on here and I do like that
do out and feed birds but if it weren't
for the fact that ganja Sufi has such a
unique voice that he's always changing
up with different breathing styles and
pitches and inflections and effects I
think I'd be pretty bored with much of
this album there are some songs on here
though that kind of seemed to come to
come together with a really strong song
hook and sound like the blame which has
this
very dark beat and these strange little
synthesizers just kind of droning away
in the background and the lyrics kind of
tell this story of violence and murder
and maybe even kind of killing for your
beliefs and also shame and the song
nickels and dimes too which is kind of
about leading a wasteful lifestyle and
one should do his or her best to avoid
that and I really like how that track
kind of transitions into the song rubber
band and you know if we are going to get
less material I I at least wish that
more of the tracks on here did that you
know just so everything didn't feel so
dis dis disconnected on this new LP I
think going to Sufi is still pushing an
original sound I'm happy he's been able
to maintain it while kind of relying on
himself more to pull this music together
muzzle is definitely a little more
cohesive but I think you know the way
that a Sufi and the killer jumped around
just so so boldly is part of what made
that album so fun it kind of like
short-circuited my brain in contrast
muzzle kind of feels like the same drug
that I've been taking but it's just not
as strong as it used to be overall I'm
still addicted to a Sufi and a killer
but if this is your first hit of ganja
Sufi you know just try it
maybe it'll freak you out and get you to
see colors I like this thing but only a
little kind of feeling like a strong six
just would have liked to have more
variation in the beats longer songs more
songs newer sounds but what do you think
of this thing do you love it do you hate
it why and what should I review next
anthony Fantana go into Sufi forever
